A new principal appointment was announced at tonight’s Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education meeting.

Andrea Runyon was named principal at Greenway Park Elementary. She has been the assistant principal at Greenway Park Elementary since 2016. Runyon was an assistant principal at Olde Providence Elementary from 2012 to 2016, a teacher at J.H. Gunn Elementary from 2010 to 2012 and a teacher assistant at the Paideia Academy at Oakhurst from 2007 to 2009. She was a teacher at Blythe Elementary from 2004 to 2006, Joseph W. Grier Academy from 2002 to 2004 and Woodrow Wilson Elementary in Kannapolis City Schools from 2000 to 2002.

Runyon earned a bachelor’s degree in education from Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, and a master’s degree in school administration from Queen’s University of Charlotte.

While there is no good time to have cancer, Wil Loesel is thankful for the timing of his stage-four non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma. "I started treatment right as we went into remote learning in March," he said. "I just finished my last treatment on Sunday, the day before school started. It would have broken my heart to not be there for my students on the first day." After months of treatment, Loesel's doctors are optimistic about his future. He has completed treatment and will soon have tests to measure his progress. "Everything has gone as well as we could have hoped," he said. "My immune system is virtually nonexistent right now. It will be a while before I can go back out into the world."
Discover more: https://www.cms.k12.nc.us/News/Pages/Teaching-with-courage.aspx

When Spencer Swindler hears people say that the 2016 Orlando Pulse Nightclub shooting or 2017 Las Vegas shooting is the largest massacre in U.S. history, he thinks, "Oh my God. We've got a lot of work to do."

The Mallard Creek High history teacher said there are many massacres, such as Wounded Knee or Black Wall Street, that have been forgotten or, even worse, not taught at all. As the world struggles with issues of racial justice, many Americans are just now learning about the Tulsa Massacre of 1921. "This is a huge massacre that we just skip over in our history books," said Swindler.

A more well-known figure in Black history, educator and author Booker T. Washington dubbed Tulsa, Okla., Black Wall Street. "He visited the city and saw that there were Black-owned businesses and Black people of all different socioeconomic statuses," said Swindler "There still wasn't an equal playing field for African-Americans. Once they cleared all those hurdles, the Black community was still seen as lesser than."

Read more: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wQMDb9OVi9A&feature=youtu.be

When Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools transitioned to digital learning in March, many worried about the students who may be left behind. After weeks of remote learning, there were many students who had not been in contact with any of their teachers. That's why the Street Team was created.

Comprised of 36 counselors, social workers, psychologists and other support staff, the team went into the community to knock on doors and try to contact nearly 2,000 students. The volunteers came from schools all over the district and were a diverse mix of elementary, middle and high school staff.

"It was a scary idea that these kids could just drop off the radar," said Marina Leonidas attendance and truancy specialist. "We knew what could be going on in these homes and wanted to make sure these kids are OK."

Read more.
https://www.cms.k12.nc.us/News/Pages/Team-hits-the-street-to-support-students.aspx

Like their school's mascot, seniors at John Taylor Williams Secondary Montessori are Trailblazers.

These students have already made history as the first ninth-grade Montessori class in Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools. They studied in a wing at Sedgefield Middle, alongside the seventh- and eighth-grade Montessori program. The next fall, they led the opening of J.T. Williams, the first public Montessori high school in North Carolina.

Now, the 13-member Class of 2020 is their school's first graduating class. The accomplishment is even greater in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, which closed schools in March. With other seniors, they shared the challenges of remote learning and the sorrow of missing once-in-a-lifetime events.

Learn more: https://www.cms.k12.nc.us/News/Pages/Senior-story-J.T.-Williams-Class-of-2020.aspx

The Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools Class of 2020 was offered scholarships totaling $153.8 million, the district announced June 16. The total is more than $6 million higher than the class of 2019’s $147.7 million.

In all, the 2020 graduates were offered 3,380 scholarships. The scholarship money offered to CMS students is an increase over the past two years.

Three of the district’s high schools received scholarship offers totaling more than $10 million. The highest total was reported by Mallard Creek High, with $15.1 million. William A. Hough High reported nearly $14 million, South Mecklenburg High reported $12.8 million.

Of the 2020 total, nearly $131 million represented academic scholarships. Athletic scholarships totaled $23 million. The scholarship offers are an important indicator of district success because they show that CMS graduates are attractive to colleges and universities.

When schools closed in March due to the COVID-19 pandemic, cafeteria manager Cynthia Graves immediately started worrying about her students from Nations Ford Elementary. Many of them were struggling with food insecurity before the pandemic. "They tell us things about how hard their lives can be outside of school," she said. "I know some of them only get meals when they are in school."

Within 24 hours, School Nutrition Services set up nearly 70 mobile distribution sites and has served more than 1 million meals since March 17. Graves and her team serve between 500 and 550 meals per day at Nations Ford.

Read more here: https://www.cms.k12.nc.us/News/Pages/Cafeteria-manager-provides-essential-services-during-pandemic.aspx

As the world adjusted in March to stay-at-home orders and social distancing, Wil Loesel was making even bigger adjustments. He was diagnosed with cancer.

After months of feeling fatigued and battling a sore throat, Loesel sought treatment. He developed a large bump on his neck that caused breathing difficulties. After many tests and specialist visits, the Albemarle Road Middle teacher found out that he has stage-four non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma. It is a rare type, called a triple-hit lymphoma. Loesel is currently undergoing an experimental, in-patient treatment, but that isn't stopping him from teaching, even from his hospital room. He teaches daily and stays in contact with his 117 eighth-grade math students through Zoom, sometimes while receiving high doses of chemotherapy.

Learn more: https://www.cms.k12.nc.us/News/Pages/Teaching-cancer-a-lesson.aspx

Dotha Howell is inspired to teach because of teachers she had as a child. "I was a very quiet child," she said. "I had a severe speech problem. I finally had a teacher, Ms. Wall, who told me that I didn't have a speech problem. I was processing too quickly. I needed to slow down and process thoughts. I had dynamic teachers who saw the greatness in me."

Today, Howell is a teacher assistant at Reid Park Academy. She was recently named the Central 1 Learning Community Teacher Assistant of the Year. "Ms. Howell exemplifies what it means to be all in," said Principal Samantha Mazzone. "When Ms. Howell sees a need, she graciously fills it. Ms. Howell is a champion for the students she works with on a daily basis. She provides all the students on her caseload with targeted instruction toward their unique learning goals."

Read more: https://www.cms.k12.nc.us/News/Pages/Dotha-Howell-Finding-greatness.aspx

McClintock Middle STEAM Coordinator Kristopher Gorman has been making thin, plastic parts, which he calls Ear Savers, for facial masks. The parts relieve tension around the ears for all-day wear. He has printed 400 with "Team CMS" on the back and is working with his principal, Mark McHugh, and other CMS staff to assist with distribution.

Gorman is doing his part to help CMS staff who work at meal sites. He and other CMS Career and Technical Education (CTE) staff from various schools worked with Charlotte MEDI early in the COVID-19 crisis as part of a growing number of community printing partners using 3-D printers to produce personal protective equipment (PPE). That project is beginning to wind down, but distribution has continued. Gorman and others are still finding ways to continue to contribute.

Read more: https://www.cms.k12.nc.us/News/Pages/United-in-compassion.aspx

post_text: Yaretzy Martinez, a seventh-grader at Coulwood STEM Academy, knows her way around technology. She's been learning how to code since fifth grade and is currently part of her school's Girls That Code Club. She and two of her classmates built a toy-sized car and created the coding that controls it. Yaretzy has also mastered the art of flying drones, which is a skill that can lead to potential jobs in the fast-growing drone industry or a broader career in aviation. Now, she and the other students at her school will be exposed to even more options in aviation and aerospace, thanks to a partnership between Honeywell and Carolinas Aviation Museum (CAM). The Student Climate Survey is administered annually to CMS students in grades 5-12, asking questions about the climate of our schools. The voluntary survey asks a range of questions on student efficacy, persistence, safety, belonging and bullying. Lastly, demographic data is collected, including gender identity and race.

This is the first year questions were added regarding student sexual identity. As much as the information collected is anonymous, the district is evaluating including those questions in the future.

School-level responses are provided to schools and reported federally by our Title IX office. No student, teacher, or classroom-level results are shared. Results are shared by grade-level for all students (no disaggregation). Only school-wide results are disaggregated by gender and race. Our team works diligently to maintain the privacy and anonymity of every respondent.

This year was the first time schools had an opportunity to review and work with the data, and we are in the early stages of determining what that work will look like.
